description: From Middle English [Term?], borrowed from Old French malice, from Latin malitia (“badness, bad quality, ill-will, spite”), from malus (“bad”).

entries.meaning: Intention to harm or deprive in an illegal or immoral way. Desire to take pleasure in another's misfortune.
(law) An intention to do injury to another party, which in many jurisdictions is a distinguishing factor between the crimes of murder and manslaughter.

verbs.description: malice (third-person singular simple present malices, present participle malicing, simple past and past participle maliced)

entries.meaning: To intend to cause harm; to bear malice.
